channel.title: Bloomberg Markets
channel.copyright: Copyright 2025 BLOOMBERG L.P. ALL RIGHTS RESERVED

item.title: Trump, Putin Phone Call on Ukraine Expected Monday
item.description: Vladimir Putin is expected to speak on a phone call Monday with Donald Trump as Washington presses for a quick end to Russia’s war in Ukraine. The call comes after Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskiy held talks in Rome on Sunday with Vice President JD Vance. Oliver Crook reports on Bloomberg Television.

item.title: Treasuries, Stocks Slide in Retreat From US Assets: Markets Wrap
item.description: US bonds, stocks and the dollar dropped after Moody’s Ratings stripped the government of its top credit rating, reinforcing concern about the status of American assets. Gold rose.
item.dc:creator: Andre Janse Van Vuuren, Julien Ponthus

item.title: Trump Tax Bill Advances as GOP Speeds Up Medicaid Cuts
item.description: President Donald Trump’s giant tax and spending package was approved by the House Budget Committee Sunday after Republican hardliners won agreement from party leaders to speed up cuts to Medicaid health coverage. Josh Gallu reports on Bloomberg Television.

item.title: Moody’s Gives Fresh Impetus to Bond Vigilantes and Stock Bears
item.description: The 30-year yield is jumping above 5%.
item.dc:creator: Alice Gledhill, Michael Mackenzie, Phil Serafino

item.title: Cathie Wood: Yes Tesla Brand Damage Has Happened
item.description:
ARK Invest founder, CEO, and CIO Cathie Wood has told Bloomberg Radio that Tesla's brand has been hurt by Elon Musk's involvement in politics. Speaking to Caroline Hepker and Tom Mackenzie on Bloomberg Daybreak Europe, Cathie Wood said, "Brand damage, yes, it has happened."
The comments come just weeks after data showed that Tesla registered only 512 new vehicles in April in the UK. Figures from the Society of Motor Manufacturers and Traders showed that new vehicle registrations were down 62% from a year earlier. Tesla's plunge was even more pronounced in Denmark, the Netherlands, and Sweden, with sales dropping by at least two-thirds in each country. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Starmer Makes Late Fishing Concession to Seal EU-UK Deal
item.description: British and European Union negotiators reached a deal overnight to strengthen their relationship after the UK agreed to extend fishing rights until 2038, according to people familiar with the discussions and documents seen by Bloomberg.
item.dc:creator: Alberto Nardelli, Alex Wickham, Jorge Valero

media:content.media:description: Fishermen gut freshly caught fish while trawling in the English Channel.

item.title: Tycoon Li’s FWD Is Said to File for HK IPO as Soon as Monday
item.description: FWD Group Holdings Ltd., an insurer backed by billionaire Richard Li, is close to filing a fresh application for an initial public offering in Hong Kong, according to people familiar with the matter.
item.dc:creator: Manuel Baigorri

media:content.media:description: An advertisement for FWD Group Holdings Ltd. in Hong Kong.

item.title: FTSE 100 Live: UK Stocks and Bonds Caught in US-Led Selloff
Aluminum Slides as Surging Inventories Add to Downbeat Mood
item.description: Aluminum prices fell as a surge in exchange stockpiles exacerbated a risk-off mood seen in the wake of Moody’s downgrade of US debt and mixed economic data from China.
item.dc:creator: Martin Ritchie, Mark Burton

item.title: Treasuries, Dollar Fall as Moody’s Sharpens Focus on US Debt
item.description: Long-dated Treasuries fell on Monday as investor attention turned to the US’s ballooning debt after Moody’s Ratings stripped the nation of its last top credit rating.
item.dc:creator: Alice Atkins, Naomi Tajitsu

item.title: Morgan Stanley’s Wilson Says Buy US Stock Dips After Moody’s Cut
item.description: Investors should buy any dips in US stocks fueled by Friday’s credit rating cut, as the trade truce with China has reduced the odds of a recession, according to Morgan Stanley’s Michael Wilson.
item.dc:creator: Sagarika Jaisinghani

item.title: Spain Boosts Costlier Gas Power to Secure Grid After Blackout
item.description: Spain is boosting generation from costlier gas-fired power plants in the wake of a nationwide blackout that raised concerns about the grid’s ability to cope with an abundance of renewable energy.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Gualtieri

media:content.media:description: Pedestrians walk along an unlit street during a power outage in Molins de Rei, Spain, on April 28.

item.title: Gold Markets Are Cited by ECB as a Risk to Financial Stability
item.description: Gold markets could be a source of danger to the euro zone’s financial stability in the event of geopolitical stress, the European Central Bank said.
item.dc:creator: Craig Stirling

media:content.media:description: Gold bars at a precious metals refinery plant in Italy.

item.title: M&A Target Stocks Surge in Bet on Wall Street Dealmaking Rebound
item.description: A group of US stocks that Citigroup Inc. considers to be acquisition targets is staging an outsize rally, underscoring Wall Street’s renewed optimism that dealmaking will revive along with the economy as tariff worries ease.
item.dc:creator: Yiqin Shen

item.title: India Top Court Rejects Airtel, Vodafone Waiver Pleas
item.description: India’s Supreme Court has rejected Bharti Airtel Ltd.’s and Vodafone Idea Ltd.’s petitions seeking a waiver on dues owed to the government.
item.dc:creator: Sanjai P R, Shruti Mahajan

media:content.media:description: Signage for Bharti Airtel Ltd. stands outside a mobile phone store in Mumbai, India, on Sunday, Jan. 19, 2020. Telecom companies including Bharti and Vodafone Idea Ltd. have sought more time from India's top court to pay $13 billion in past dues as they plan to negotiate with the government, people with knowledge of the matter said.

item.title: Gold Gains as Dollar Slides Following Moody’s US Downgrade
item.description: Gold rose as the dollar tumbled after Moody’s Ratings downgraded the US government’s top credit rating, blaming successive administrations’ inability to cut a ballooning budget deficit.
item.dc:creator: Yihui Xie, Jack Ryan

item.title: Ant Group Global Unit Brings in $3 Billion Ahead of Spinoff
item.description: Jack Ma-backed Ant Group Co.’s international division generated nearly $3 billion in revenue for 2024, according to people familiar with the matter, setting the stage for a spinoff after the unit set up its own board last year.
item.dc:creator: Lulu Yilun Chen

media:content.media:description: The Ant Group Co. mascot at the company's headquarters in Hangzhou, China. Photographer: Qilai Shen/Bloomberg

item.title: China Gave Pakistan Air Defense, Satellite Support, Says Indian Defense Ministry Research Group
item.description: A research group under India's Ministry of Defence says China provided Pakistan with air defense and satellite support during its recent clash with India. India's planning for conflicts with Pakistan now accounts for the probability that China will provide assistance to Islamabad, with India factoring in a "two-front situation" in its calculations. Bloomberg Sudhi Ranjan Sen speaks to Haslinda Amin on Insight With Haslinda Amin. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Cathie Wood Says Trump’s Tariff War May Free Up Markets
item.description: Cathie Wood sees a potential turning point for stock markets following the volatility sparked by US President Donald Trump’s tariff announcements in April.
item.dc:creator: Leonard Kehnscherper, Kriti Gupta, Guy Johnson

media:content.media:description: Cathie Wood, chief executive officer of Ark Investment Management LLC, during a Bloomberg Television interview in London, UK, on Monday, May 19, 2025. We expect real GDP in the US to accelerate, Wood said.

item.title: Oil Edges Lower With Ukraine War Talks, US Outlook in Focus
item.description: Oil edged lower, with talks to end the war in Ukraine and a reduction of the US credit rating in focus.
item.dc:creator: Yongchang Chin, Alex Longley

media:content.media:description: Exxon Mobil Corp. oil drilling rigs near Stanton, Texas, US, on Saturday, March 15, 2025. The Permian Basin, a sprawling shale patch that lies beneath Texas and New Mexico, is North America's most prolific shale patch.

item.title: Euro-Area Inflation to Fall Below 2% on US Tariffs, EU Predicts
item.description: Euro-area inflation will fall below the European Central Bank’s target next year because of fallout from US trade policies, according to the European Commission.
item.dc:creator: Alexander Weber

media:content.media:description: The headquarters of the European Central Bank (ECB) beyond containers at a freight terminal in Frankfurt.

item.title: In Full: Ark's Wood on AI, Tech, Health Care, US Economy
item.description: Cathie Wood, the founder, CEO and chief investment officer of Ark Investment Management, discusses artificial intelligence and its impact on the US technology and health care industries as well as Elon Musk's government efficiency project. Speaking on Bloomberg Television she also comments on President Donald Trump's tariff policies and their impact on the US economy. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Deutsche Bank Makes a Comeback to Win Top German IPO Roles
item.description: Deutsche Bank AG is again getting top roles in Germany’s biggest initial public offerings, marking a significant comeback in a business that it pared back about six years ago.
item.dc:creator: Eyk Henning, Swetha Gopinath, Arno Schuetze

media:content.media:description: The Deutsche Bank AG headquarters in the financial district of Frankfurt, Germany, on Thursday, Feb. 1, 2024. Deutsche Bank plans to cut 3,500 jobs over the coming years as Chief Executive Officer Christian Sewing seeks to make good on a pledge to lift profitability and return more money to shareholders.

item.title: Bond Investors Detect Trouble in US Debt Stripped of AAA Rating
item.description: Even before talk of fresh unfunded tax cuts took center stage in the budget wrangling on Capitol Hill, US bond investors were making their views loud and clear: If the government keeps spending more than it takes in, there will be consequences.
item.dc:creator: Michael Mackenzie, Alice Gledhill

media:content.media:description: Bessent speaks during a House hearing on Tuesday, May 6, 2025. The Treasury secretary acknowledged US debt is on an unsustainable path.

item.title: Romanian Assets Rally on Election With Budget Woes Now in Focus
item.description: Romania’s assets staged a relief rally after a centrist candidate defeated his nationalist opponent in the presidential election, with investor focus now shifting to how quickly a new government can fix the state’s finances.
item.dc:creator: Irina Vilcu, Andra Timu

item.title: Polish Markets Get Hit After Race for President Tightens
item.description: Polish assets slipped after a stronger-than-expected showing by opposition populists in the first round of the presidential election, boding badly for the pro-European government and its centrist candidate.
item.dc:creator: Konrad Krasuski, Agnieszka Barteczko

media:content.media:description: Rafal Trzaskowski, mayor of Warsaw, center, waves a Polish flag during an election night rally in Sandomierz, Poland, on Sunday, May 18, 2025. Trzaskowski, the centrist Warsaw mayor, and Karol Nawrocki, a pro-Donald Trump nationalist, came neck-and-neck in the first round of Poland's presidential election, according to an exit poll, in a blow to the pro-European government.

item.title: Cathie Wood Is Bullish on Broader US Technology Sector
item.description: Cathie Wood, the founder, CEO and chief investment officer of Ark Investment Management, discusses the outlook for US technology investments as more firms use artificial intelligence to reduce the cost of innovation. Speaking on Bloomberg Television, Wood says she expects the gains that have benefited the top US firms to broaden out to the wider sector.

item.title: Scott Bok on How Bankers Spread the Gospel of Capitalism
item.description: How investment bankers pushed the idea of shareholder maximization.
item.dc:creator: Tracy Alloway, Joe Weisenthal

media:content.media:description: Scott Bok, chief executive officer of Greenhill & Co., speaks during a Bloomberg Television interview in New York, U.S., on Friday, Jan. 27, 2017. Bok discussed the firm's fourth-quarter results and what he sees for the M&A market in 2017 under President Donald Trump. Photographer: Christopher Goodney/Bloomberg

item.title: Russia Says China’s Zijin Agrees to Keep Siberian Zinc Mine Open
item.description: Russia’s Tuva region said it has agreed with Zijin Mining Group to keep the Kyzyl-Tashtyg zinc mine working after sanctions prompted the Chinese company to weigh suspending operations.
item.dc:creator: Yuliya Fedorinova

media:content.media:description: A sign outside a Zijin Mining complex. Photographer: Oliver Bunic/Bloomberg

item.title: Odd Lots: Scott Bok on How Bankers Boosted Capitalism (Podcast)
item.description: When we think about the prospect of deglobalization (whatever that means) we often think about it in terms of the goods economy. Supply chains get rerouted. Manufacturing becomes more localized, and possibly less efficient. But changes to the global world order also have implications for Wall Street, and the world of dealmaking. On this episode of the podcast, we speak with Scott Bok, the former chairman and CEO of the investment bank Greenhill & Co., which is now part of Mizuho. Scott is th
item.dc:creator: Tracy Alloway, Joe Weisenthal
